text: I had a pretty good childhood my family
weren't rich we were close though and I
had friends to play with
we were not angels but we were in bad
kids either
Sabino was my best mate
Sabino finished school at 13 he couldn't
afford the fees I liked school but I
missed my friend
Sabino had to work until sundown he
never complained but I knew he wanted to
be back at school at 17 I finished
school and there was no work time
dragged in 2006 a fishing boat sank off
the coast spilling a large cargo that
washed up on the shore back then we
didn't know what the white powder was
though people found many uses for it I
got my hands on a few kilos I didn't
know what the powder was either a friend
told me the powder was worth a lot of
money to some Lebanese businessman so I
ran home and fetched it I saw that bag
for $9,000 that mysterious white powder
was cocaine I thought it was the best
day of my life
I didn't know it then but it was
actually the worst I wouldn't believe my
good luck I invested my money and got
into the taxi business
Sabino became my driver the money rolled
in life was good I dreamed of fleets of
taxis a business empire we worked so
hard to build that dream rising with the
Sun and then collapsing late at night we
all wanted an easier life tempted by any
shortcut we could find to get there but
some of us found it easier to resist
than others I felt on top of the world
most nights I drank and partied I
thought I was invincible and then I
tried crack I was feeling so good
already so happy with everything but
crack took me to another place business
was good Sabino did the hard driving
nerves of steel but I neglected my
business
Sabino tried to help me but I didn't
want to know when you've got crack in
your life you don't listen to anyone
you're constantly looking for that next
hit that next opportunity to score - for
deeper and deeper
my business crumbled around me I had to
sell my taxi for next to nothing
I had no choice my family couldn't
believe it
what a fool had been I didn't want to
believe that I had lost it all
they threw me out out on the street
left with nothing just that hunger that
was still there that craving for crack
the money I got for the taxi or went in
a couple of months when you're smoking
crack you don't even notice it go but
there's always money when you know where
to look it's no fortune but it will buy
crack for a few days I know she needs
the cash to eat but I can't help it my
hunger is worse than hers crack can mess
anyone up doesn't matter who you are
this guy Musa used to be a top striker
in the guinea-bissau Premier League I
used to watch him play but when I was in
the money now his calls in a different
kind of way he used to be special now
just another addict
it was the dangerous life but all that
mattered was the stash once it would
have scared me he might come back with a
gun tomorrow but when you smoking crack
there is no tomorrow
there is only now this only crack
one by one I lost my friends and family
my ties to the real world
I didn't even care when my father died
the one relationship that mattered was
with my crack pipe now I go through
waves of feeling happy and disappointed
with my life I think about my dad a lot
when I'm sober
he died disappointed with me but there's
always crack that hunger is always there
there is this one place that head of
outside of the city
it's a rehabilitation center those guys
there had reached rock bottom tied up
like dogs that desire for crack
that's the worst it scares me even to
think about that place and even if I
went there what would it all be for what
would be different once I left it's
still going to be the same odd story
isn't it I am 29 no wife and no kids
well that I know of no job and no future
what is there apart from crack
